instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S0_ALSCAM_F: What is PP5V_S0_ALSCAM_F? PP5V_S0_ALSCAM is a power rail for the webcam and the ambient light sensor..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the batteryâ€™s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
My reference only: TT10011

Issue: Screen is not producing picture, no external video either.

History: Very small amount of corrosion found at TP: <SIGNAL>GPU_CLKREQ_L_R</SIGNAL> (just below <CAPACITOR>C1951</CAPACITOR>), I did not at first think the corrosion was touching anything except the metal casing on the board. I ended up replacing <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> because I was not getting 1.2v where I should have been. The higher voltages at first were present. After looking back at TP GPU_CLKREQ_L__R, I cleaned it up and the center pad was gone, I tried to scrape the board with a diamond tipped pen but I could not get the solder to adhere. There was however part of the trace from this TP still there. I scraped that area and routed a jumper wire from there to <RESISTOR>R1945</RESISTOR> pin 2. Continuity to those areas checked out. I am however not getting any S5. I keep coming back to <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> being a possible issue?

USB-C meter shows 20v but pulls almost no amps other then when first plugging in it shoots up to .27 amps but drops to about .02 amps thereafter but maintains 20v.
What should I be testing or looking for next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
Do you get expected SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages?
Is the machine recognized into DFU mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103023, member: 682"]
Do you get expected SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages?
Is the machine recognized into DFU mode?
[/QUOTE]
I get <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>, which AWAKE are you referring to? 
I have not tried DFU, let me give that a shot now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="prodigy83, post: 103025, member: 32178"]
I have not tried DFU, let me give that a shot now.
[/QUOTE]
I forced it in to DFU mode, had no problem in doing so, but getting to step 4 of 4, the progress bar stops at the last word, then it gave me this exact same error both times while trying to do the revive (see image). The customer has files that are not backed up so cannot try the restore. Which AWAKE were you asking me to check out?

Just tried again after updating my Mac to Sonoma, was reading this was supposed to fix this error but still the revive did not work.
Update: Finally convinced the customer to let me try the restore. That did not work either. Same thing with same error.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
If machine enters DFU, all necessary SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages should be present.
You should reflash SoC ROM and try again DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
I am using the CH341A programmer but I do not have the circuit board to solder the chip on to. You had me once before go to PCBway.com to order the WSON-8 setup. Where can I find or order this so this chip can be read? Also, I know this is a 1.8v chip, anything I need to do to make sure the CH441A is not going to fry this chip?

Nevermind! I guess the USON-8 worked. The two extra pins in the middle were throwing me off. I found the board bin files but it comes with two files. One ends in <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and the other ends in UB090. Not sure which one I am supposed to use. I guess I will try them both.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
The above mentioned files are for left/right TBT ROM.
You need to flash <CHIP>U4770</CHIP>.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1EF4nvQCUzYOKFg_37zCrfq1KvgrvKO8B/view?usp=sharing[/URL]
Sometime helps just erasing it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
Thanks, I did erase it first and then programmed the file you provided. At first it did not work, then I plugged in the trackpad and battery, this worked doing a Restore. What I am seeing though is when I plug the motherboard in to power, it ramps up to about .27amps, then drops to about .10amps. No video still. Still getting a good constant 20v.

I am getting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> but it seems like the lower voltage like <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> I do not get. This is confusing, how can I get S0 for the camera, but no S5 for the lower voltage?
I get no <SIGNAL>PP2V5_S3</SIGNAL>.
I have <SIGNAL>P5V_3V3G3H_EN</SIGNAL>
No <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.
No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> is giving12.59v.
<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is good.
I get 1.8v at <RESISTOR>R7670</RESISTOR> so this looks good. 
What am I missing? S5 seems to be an issue here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
"This is confusing, how can I get S0 for the camera"
Check schematic, before making wrong assumption!
It comes from <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> (L8504).

Did you try original 87/96W charger?
Also test with battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103064, member: 682"]
It comes from <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> (L8504)
[/QUOTE]
Okay, I assumed you are not supposed to get S0 without first getting S5, S4, S3, and so on. Thanks for correcting me.
I am using a 140v Apple USB-C charger, I have nothing less.
When I connect the battery and battery sense cable:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_S3</SIGNAL>
Both have 0v.
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> has 12.59v.
I am however getting <CHIP>U8250</CHIP> voltage at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL>, but no voltage out at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL>.
Sensor issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
Do you get any other G3S voltage?
Apart of <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.
SSD gets any voltage?

S0 is the last state in power on sequence.
God knows why Apple used <SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_ALSCAM</SIGNAL> name: it is directly derived from <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103071, member: 682"]
Do you get any other G3S voltage?
[/QUOTE]
Yes, I have <SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_X</SIGNAL> all are present.
Yes! <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL>. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> are all present and stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message: Then you should get L7600 voltage; check diode mode to ground there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103099, member: 682"]
Then you should get L7600 voltage; check diode mode to ground there.
[/QUOTE]
I sure do, .398. Openboard data shows this is pretty close.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> in diode mode shows .166. It is supposed to be .182. Is that too far off?
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE is .398 which also looks off, I do however get .8 volts here.
Still no <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
There must be something more affected by corrosion.
Possibly accumulated crap underneath BGA chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
This pad in the pink circle was completley gone because of corrosion. I ran a jumper wire from a trace it was once conncted to which has continuity to <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 2 after I ran that jumper wire to <RESISTOR>R1945</RESISTOR> pin 2. All continuity is present. I ran some flux under <CHIP>U1200</CHIP> just in case any corrosion but still no <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL>. I noticed I get voltage to RK022 pin 1 but nothing to pin 2. This is a debug resistor so I am not sure if voltage should be going here.
I do also get 1.8v at RK018 pin 1.
No voltage at PPVCCPRIMCORE_PRIM_REG.
I get <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> .539v which seems slightly low? I turned it off (the power) and back on and it did jump to .900v then dropped back down to the .539v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
You don't get pulse on any S5 power rail?
Just in case, reflow/reball <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
May need to reball PCH too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103146, member: 682"]
You don't get pulse on any S5 power rail?
Just in case, reflow/reball <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
May need to reball PCH too.
[/QUOTE]
On <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> I get .102v ONLY when I first turn it on very briefly, but it drops to .002v right after. No Pulsing.
I reflowed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, still nothing.
Diode mode measures .325 on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
The USB-C meter still shows 20v and at first the amps draw .28, but then drops to .17, then to .0 amps and stays there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
"I get voltage to RK022 pin 1 but nothing to pin 2."
RK018 is also 0 ohm.
If resistors are placed there, replace them.

Please, do not quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
Okay, sorry about that.
No physical resistors present. I reflowed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1200</CHIP>, no change.
I get <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8250</CHIP> but nothing on <SIGNAL>SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3SSW_SNS</SIGNAL>.
Replace <CHIP>U8250</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message: I still suspect something damaged by corrosion; not easy to find...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP1V8_GPU</SIGNAL> is not present, fried GPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message:
I don't exactly know the place of this voltage in power sequence; may appear later.
Give a try lifting one side the GPU core coils (all).
Not sure for this board, but 01700 stays on and chimes in such case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Video
threads.message: This board never chimed at all. The only thing that comes to mind is the onboard RAM may be the problem area. I have decided to call it quits on this repair but I sincerley really appreciate your ongoing help and support.
